title: Well, ok
author: Well, ok
content: I have a btc wallet that received Bitcoin Cash in the 2017 hard fork.If I sweep the private key into my Electrum Bitcoin wallet, do the BCH, Bitcoin SV and other airdrops remain attached to the private key?Once I sweep the key into Electrum, can I then sweep the same private key into another client that supports BCH and etc?Many thanks!

comments.author: Findingnemo
comments.body: Quote from: Well, ok on September 13, 2023, 05:32:55 PMIf I sweep the private key into my Electrum Bitcoin wallet, do the BCH, Bitcoin SV and other airdrops remain attached to the private key?Yes, Sweeping the private keys into electrum will give access to the Bitcoins associated with that address.Quote from: Well, ok on September 13, 2023, 05:32:55 PMOnce I sweep the key into Electrum, can I then sweep the same private key into another client that supports BCH and etc?Yes.You can import the same private keys on Coinomi to access the BCH.If you need any help regarding claiming the hard-forked coins then use : LoyceV's Bitcoin Fork claiming guide (and service)

comments.author: odolvlobo
comments.body: Quote from: Well, ok on September 13, 2023, 05:32:55 PMI have a btc wallet that received Bitcoin Cash in the 2017 hard fork.That's not really what happened. It was not an "airdrop". In simple terms, Bitcoin Cash duplicated the existing Bitcoin block chain at the time. So, for all the Bitcoin addresses you control, you also control the equivalent Bitcoin Cash addresses and the BCH they might contain.Quote from: Well, ok on September 13, 2023, 05:32:55 PMIf I sweep the private key into my Electrum Bitcoin wallet, do the BCH, Bitcoin SV and other airdrops remain attached to the private key?Nothing you do with Bitcoin affects Bitcoin Cash, Bitcoin SV, or any of the many other forks.

comments.author: LoyceV
comments.body: Quote from: Well, ok on September 13, 2023, 05:32:55 PMOnce I sweep the key into Electrum, can I then sweep the same private key into another client that supports BCH and etc?Yes and no: yes you can do this, but no it might not work as you expected. Not all Forkcoins have replay protection, which means they can move on multiple chains when you send one of them. Getting some Forkcoin dust and including it in your transaction prevents that.Sweep your Bitcoin to a new address first, then the most valuable Forkcoin and continue down from there. Also be careful in installing Fork wallets, people have lost their funds by using compromised wallets.

comments.author: Well, ok
comments.body: Thanks everyone! Do I need to prepend the private key (starts with 5) with anything when sweeping it into electrum?

comments.author: Pmalek
comments.body: Quote from: Well, ok on September 22, 2023, 05:09:41 PMThanks everyone! Do I need to prepend the private key (starts with 5) with anything when sweeping it into electrum?  I think Electrum has an information or question mark button that shows examples of the prefixes you need to enter before the private keys. Just make sure you enter one key per line and not one after the other or with commas in between or something like that. The prefix you need to enter will depend on the type of address you have and with what character it starts. I am guessing that you are using legacy addresses starting with "1". In that case, I think you need to enter "P2PKH:" But click the info button to be sure.

comments.author: Well, ok
comments.body: Yea, it's a legacy address beginning with 1. Thank you for the help.

comments.author: hosemary
comments.body: Quote from: Pmalek on September 22, 2023, 06:19:11 PMI am guessing that you are using legacy addresses starting with "1". In that case, I think you need to enter "P2PKH:" But click the info button to be sure. Right. With using the prefix "p2pkh:" when importing/sweeping a private key, you tell electrum that you want the legacy address. If your address is legacy, you can also enter the private key without any prefix. That works whether the private key is uncompressed (starts with 5) or it's compressed (starts with K or L).
